channel.title: Arts, Music, Theatre - News, Pictures and Reviews | Mail Online
channel.description: Check out the latest news, pictures and reviews on arts events, exhibitions, theatre shows and albums releases from the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday

image.title: Arts, Music, Theatre - News, Pictures and Reviews | Mail Online

item.title: Emma Hack's art where nude models blend into graphic backgrounds gets 500m hits online
item.description: Emma Hacks, from Australia, will spend up to 15 hours painting a naked model live at the Rebecca Hossack Gallery in London.
item.media:description: Emma

item.title: Make-up artist Maria Malone-Guerbaa creates face painting transformation
item.description: Maria Malone-Guerbaa, 33, from Limerick, Ireland, is able to create a perfect likeness of other famous faces including A-list stars Morgan Freeman and The Queen.
item.media:description: make up

item.title: Bali 9 death row inmate Myuran Sukumaran's paintings not eligible for Archibald Prize
item.description: The 33-year-old has been locked up in Kerobokan Prison, Bali, since 2005 after he was convicted of heroin smuggling. He only began painting in 2010.
item.media:description: Passionate: Sukumaran took up painting 2010. He now runs an art studio at the jail. Here he is seen painting on a canvas at the prisoners studio

item.title: Artist, 24, creates stunning sculptures using beaches as her blank canvas just one month after picking up a rake for first time
item.description: Chloe Dickey drew a huge floral design on a Port Macquarie beach on Saturday in under two hours.
item.media:description: Chloe Dickey began sand sculpting less than a month ago. She is pictured at Flagstaff Beach in Port Macquarie, NSW

item.title: Artist creates World Cup players' portraits with paint-covered football
item.description: 'Red' Hong Yi produced colorful renderings of Portugal’s Cristiano Ronaldo, Brazil’s Neymar and Argentina’s Lionel Messi.
item.media:description: Having a ball: 'Red' Hong Yi creates paintings of World Cup stars Cristiano Ronaldo, Neymar and Lionel Messi using her feet

item.title: Feline arty! Artist loves her pet cat so much she's added it to works by Botticelli, Dali and even the Mona Lisa
item.description: A bizarre but strangely wonderful concept of classic paintings and fine art work 'improved' by a fat ginger cat, Fat Cat Art is rapidly growing its online fan base.
item.media:description: cat art

item.title: Artist creates portraits of celebrities - using cornflakes
item.description: Illustrator and photographer Sarah Rosado used cereal to produce renderings of famous musicians, including Michael Jackson, Amy Winehouse and John Lennon.
item.media:description: Appetite for construction: Guns 'N Roses guitarist Slash is easily recognizable in his signature top hat and sunglasses

item.title: Illuminated UV paintings on women's backs celebrate beauty
item.description: John Poppleton, from California, creates mindblowing works of art painted directly onto human skin using fluorescent shades.
item.media:description: Illuminated UV paintings on women's backs celebrate beauty of female form and spectacular scenes from nature

item.title: Michelle Wibowo creates portrait of Prince William and Prince George using TOBLERONE!
item.description: The masterpiece was created by food artist Michelle Wibowo, using a staggering 16,074 individual triangles.
item.media:description: The perfect Father's Day present for Wills! Artist creates portrait of The Duke of Cambridge and baby George out of TOBLERONE!

item.title: Crumbs! Is that a Banksy? Artist trades her palette for a plate to create captivating culinary pop art
item.description: Tisha Cherry, a New Jersey-born registered nurse, takes inspiration from films, music, and celebrities, and recreates iconic images using everyday food.
item.media:description: FoodArt.jpg food art, Tisha Cherry, instagram

item.title: Banksy originals purchased for just $60 set to fetch $160,000 at auction
item.description: An art fan who unwittingly bought two paintings by street artist Banksy in Central Park for just $60 each is expected to receive a $160,000 windfall when the prints go up for auction.
item.media:description: A stall selling original, signed Banksy art popped up near New York's Central Park on Saturday, but passersby had no idea the works were authentic

item.title: Chicago artist fills in the city's potholes with mosaics
item.description: Artist Jim Bachor has been filling holes in the road in Chicago by creating mosaics which use the colours of the flag of the city and feature a fake serial number to highlight the severity of the pothole problem.
item.media:description: Jim Bachor scrapes away the cement to reveal his finished mosaic on a filled pothole in a Chicago street

item.title: Crouching tiger, hidden garden! Buddhist monk's secret paradise bursts into life
item.description: The incredible garden took 45 years to create, and is a hidden haven near the A1133 in Nottinghamshire, which has now become an unofficial tourist attraction, bringing in 10K visitors per year.

item.title: Red Dot Miami exhibits Ricardo Cardenas' Art on Concrete
item.description: Artwork to show at 16th edition Art Basel in Miami Beach

item.title: Pixacao is native to Brazil and similar in method to tagging. It's characterised by distinctive large letters painted in a cryptic style
item.description: The first thing I notice wandering through Sao Paulo is the lack of advertising. There are no billboards, outdoor video screens or ads on buses. Instead I fi...
item.media:description: Pixacao at Paulista Metro station in Sao Paulo

item.title: Uncle Vanya, Vaudeville Theatre, London: Uncle Vanya's dacha is all too wooden
item.description: Carmichael’s plaintive, plain Sonya is one of the strengths of Lindsay Posner’s exceptionally starry but disappointingly lacklustre revival. Her blushing joy when she dares to say how much she loves Astrov is wretchedly moving.
item.media:description: REGRETS, THEY'VE HAD A FEW: Anna Friel as Yelena and Ken Stott as Vanya

item.title: Lang Lang¿s a long way off
item.description: Lang Lang is a phenomenon. Apparently, 40 million Chinese kids are learning the piano because of him. His name is as familiar as that of any rock star. And technically his pianism is pretty phenomenal too.
item.media:description: Lang Lang, pianist and growing international sensation, who has apparently inspired thousands to start playing the piano

item.title: Could this be love, or just happy pills?
item.description: The Effect at the Cottesloe Theatre, is immersive. The audience is transported to luxurious private clinic. Comfy banquettes with flower arrangements double as a lab where drug trials for anti-depressants are taking place.
item.media:description: Billie Piper with Jonjo O'Neill, in The Effect by Lucy Prebble and directed by Rupert Goold at The Cottesloe Theatre

item.title: Argo review: Bristles with tension - Ben Affleck's 70s spy thriller
item.description: Argo, the new film from the increasingly admired Ben Affleck, concentrates on another tale that is so astonishing it is difficult to believe.
item.media:description: Argo tells the true story of the six Americans who managed to slip out of the embassy in Iran as the doors were being broken in

item.title: The Pilgrim's Progress review: A jailhouse Pilgrim? It really rocks
item.description: Vaughan William's would have enjoyed this production by English National Opera (London Coliseum) and felt vindicated about its original poor reception in 1951.
item.media:description: SKIRTING THE ISSUE: Lord Lechery played by Colin Judson in The Pilgrim's Progress

item.title: Alt-J, Electric Ballroom review: The nicest boys in polite rock
item.description: Alt-J are four Leeds University graduates with one claim to fame: their debut album, An Awesome Wave, has just won the Mercury Music Prize for the Album of the Year.
item.media:description: Nice Boys: (From left to right) Joe Newman, Thom Green, Gus Unger-Hamilton and Gwil Sainsbury of Alt-J after they were announced as winners of the Mercury Prize

item.title: Irish eyes are smiling at a Russian star
item.description: Francesco Cilea’s L’Arlesiana, is a sure-fire winner at this year's Wexford festival. In the young Russian tenor Dmitry Golovnin they have unearthed a future star.
item.media:description: Griopping: Eleanor Greenwood and Annuziata Vestri in L'Arlesiana

item.title: Memories of Georg the genius
item.description: A hundred years ago today Gyorgy Stern was born in Budapest. His incident-packed transformation into Sir Georg Solti, one of the most renowned classical musicians in the world by the time of his death 85 years later, is a fascinating one.
item.media:description: ENERGY PERSONIFIED: Georg Solti conducting in 1961

item.title: Swan is reborn in all her beauty: Swan Lake at the Royal Opera House
item.description: There are too many mediocre performances of this box-office cert, and one can weary of its charms. But that’s not the case with the Royal Ballet’s revival of Anthony Dowell’s 1987 production.
item.media:description: FLIGHT OF ARTISTRY: Natalia Osipova as Odette

item.title: Beckett¿s ¿Archers¿ rules the air waves: All That Fall at Jermyn Street Theatre
item.description: Jermyn Street Theatre has got permission from the estate of Samuel Beckett to stage his 1956 play All That Fall, which he wrote specifically for radio, and has cast it with two of our finest actors, Eileen Atkins and Michael Gambon.
item.media:description: All That Fall by Samuel Beckett and directed by Trevor Nunn at the Jermyn Street Theatre. Michael Gambon as Mr Rooney and Eileen Atkins as Mrs Rooney

item.title: Ed Sheeran keeps us all in the loop at the Hammersmith Apollo
item.description: From the outside, the Sheeran phenomenon is puzzling. In concert, though, he is more than the sum of his parts. Standing on stage all alone, he puts more gusto into the task than you get from some indie bands in a year.
item.media:description: Ed Sheeran performs on stage at Hammersmith Apollo, where he calls the crowd his 'gospel choir'

item.title: Our Boys: Casualties of war face the enemy within
item.description: It’s 1984. In the wake of the Falklands War and against the backdrop of the Troubles, five squaddies and an officer are laid up with injuries at the Queen Elizabeth Military Hospital in Woolwich.
item.media:description: Struggle: Laurence Fox and Matthew Lewis in Our Boys

item.title: Patriotic Parry unites a nation
item.description: Everyone knows Sir Hubert Parry’s Jerusalem, but how many know his unison song England, a setting of a paraphrase of John of Gaunt’s great patriotic speech from Shakespeare’s Richard II?
item.media:description: Perfect timing: Neeme Jarvi conducts a fascinating Works For Chorus And Orchestra by Sir Hubert Parry

item.title: Cabaret, Savoy Theatre review: Anything goes in Will Young's sexy Cabaret
item.description: Young is excellent, hitting the high notes with an effortless sweetness while something both scared and deeply scary keeps seeping through that baby face. Anything goes round here, as long as it’s sleazy.
item.media:description: Host with the most: Will Young excels as the MC in a revival of Cabaret

item.title: Wagner: The Valkyrie Royal Opera House, London review
item.description: After Twilight Of The Gods, an experienced friend confided: ‘Covent Garden is one of the world’s great opera houses, but this wasn’t one of the world’s great Rings.’ Just so. But why was it so?
item.media:description: TWISTED FATE: Susan Bullock brought sophistication to the role of Brunnhilde

item.title: Jake Bugg: Jake Bugg review: Debut album is almost too good to be true
item.description: Lest we forget how good the music of the late Fifties was, here comes a new voice who seems hellbent on reminding us. And the extraordinary thing is, he wasn’t born till 1994. Jake Bugg, an 18-year-old from Nottingham, is almost too good to be true
item.media:description: JAKE'S PROGRESS: The 18-year-old Jake Bug's debut is a near

item.title: Pre-Raphaelites Victorian Avant-Garde at the Tate Britain review
item.description: In recent years a huge enthusiasm has sprung up for them. The Tate exhibition Pre-Raphaelites: Victorian Avant-Garde, featuring some of their most striking and impressive paintings, is a certain crowd-puller.
item.media:description: VISION OF BEAUTY: Rossetti's Lady Lilith, with his mistress Fanny Cornforth as the mythic first wife of Adam

item.title: Grieving Sean can still lift our spirits
item.description: Sean Hughes was once all the rage. But his stand-up career stalled and he settled down to the slightly less stellar heights of team captain on Never Mind The Buzzcocks.
item.media:description: Sean Hughes

item.title: One-man show crowded with a cast from Dickens
item.description: You’ve probably forgotten, what with the Olympics and all, that 2012 also marks the bicentenary of Charles Dickens’s birth. It’s a fine excuse for Simon Callow to reprise Peter Ackroyd’s The Mystery Of Charles Dickens.
item.media:description: Gusto: Callow embodies Dickens

item.title: Bob Dylan: The big strumback
item.description: It doesn’t do to second-guess old Bob. Just as you’re settling in for more of the rocking-chair grandpa stuff, Tempest turns into another thing entirely.
item.media:description: Intriguing: Bob Dylan's new release is an 'old fashioned LP that would be best served by pausing to flip it over'

item.title: A hearty meal for gourmets
item.description: Stephen Hough calls his extremely generous, 79-minute, 17-item French Album ‘a sort of musical dessert trolley’, but that sells it short.
item.media:description: Connoisseur: Stephen Hough

item.title: Jumpy review: Growing pains that will make your heart bleed
item.description: Tamsin Greig’s Hilary has hit 50 and she’s feeling battered. She arrives home, weighed down by her groceries in hessian bags-for-life, but more so by misery and weariness.
item.media:description: Jagged edges: Tamsin Greig and Bel Powley as mother and daughter in Jumpy

item.title: Legend ticks all the boxes
item.description: Lovers of British music can now get the complete recorded legacy, on 23 CDs, of Sir Clifford Curzon, the greatest English pianist of the 20th Century, for less than £50 on Decca.
item.media:description: Seeking perfection: Sir Clifford Curzon practising in 1949

item.title: Office romance lifts us out of a slump
item.description: A bright, forgotten gem by J. B. Priestley unseen since 1935, Cornelius is set in the London office of aluminium importers Briggs & Murrison.
item.media:description: Give him credit: Alan Cox, with Emily Barber, is 'a joy' as the put-upon boss

item.title: Emi is simply the best in Tina Turner tribute show Soul Sister
item.description: Tina Turner tribute show Soul Sister is both made and saved by Emi Wokoma’s sensational impersonation of the glamorous diva.
item.media:description: The mane attraction: Emi Wokoma as Tina Turner in Soul Sister

item.title: Paramedic who boasted on Facebook that he 'saved someone's life and managed to cop a feel of some cracking jubblies' is found guilty of misconduct
item.description: Mark Small, of Great Western Ambulance service, was found guilty at a conduct hearing of the Health Professions Council. The panel is still considering what sanctions to take against Mr Small.
item.media:description: 'Copped a feel': Paramedic Mark Small appeared at the HPC in Kennington

item.title: Boris Johnson blasts 'dismal' MPs for refusing to beam Olympic heroes onto Parliament
item.description: Boris Johnson last night denounced ‘dismal’ MPs for refusing to project giant images of British Olympic and Paralympic heroes on to the Houses of Parliament.
item.media:description: MPs have thrown out a request by the Olympics chiefs to project images of the Games on Parliament

item.title: Pure: A unique music and whisky festival in London
item.description: This weekend the unique Pure Festival in East London that is sure to warm your cockles, by fusing top bands and musicians with whisky tasting - a heady combination.
item.media:description: Pure Festival in East London: A festival of whisky and music - but watch out if you do it in that order!

item.title: Faberge collection of the Royals goes on display in Buckingham Palace
item.description: This stunning collection of intricate works of art by Russian jeweller and goldsmith Peter Carl Fabergé is what the Royal family has amassed in more than a century.
item.media:description: Faberge

item.title: Lost Collection: Paintings left on public transport are given their own show
item.description: A London gallery is showing 60 artworks, most of them unnamed, that have been stored away in Transport For London's Lost Property Office since they were left behind.
item.media:description: Little corrections: This impressionism-inspired painting mysteriously features a windmill that has been blanked out

item.title: The REAL eau de toilet! Artist makes perfume from the 'excesses of his body'
item.description: Jammie Nicholas, a 23-year-old art student, distilled Surplus from his own excreta, urine and sebum. The limited edition fragrance costs £40 per bottle.
item.media:description: Surplus: Artist Jammie Nicholas created a perfume from his own body waste

item.title: Art collector buys £8,000 painting - and X-ray shows a £50,000 picture underneath
item.description: The art lover bought the original piece - a self-portrait by Robert Lenkiewicz depicting the artist in a nude pose with a female model - at auction for £8,500.
item.media:description: Artist Robert Lenkiewicz (right) with Edwin McKenzie, the tramp he emblamed and kept in his studio
